title: MD
biography: Stefan D. Anker is a German cardiologist who is Head of Field “Tissue Homeostasis and Cachexia" at Charité University, Berlin, Germany. Previously, he was Professor of Innovative Clinical Trials at University Medical Center Göttingen in Germany. The main focus of the Innovative Clinical Trials department was research in the field of chronic heart failure, including the development and clinical testing of new therapies.
aiSummary: Stefan D. Anker is a heart failure specialist with an H-index of 263 at Charité – Berlin (Faculty). Has been published in New England Journal of Medicine, The Lancet, Nature Reviews Cardiology. Based in Germany.

### 3. Key Procedures & Clinical Expertise

Dr. Anker's expertise lies predominantly in the field of heart failure, a complex clinical syndrome characterized by the heart's inability to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. His clinical skills likely encompass a wide range of diagnostic and therapeutic interventions aimed at improving the quality of life and survival of patients with heart failure.

His diagnostic expertise likely includes a thorough understanding of the various causes of heart failure, such as coronary artery disease, hypertension, valvular heart disease, and cardiomyopathy. He likely possesses proficiency in performing and interpreting diagnostic tests such as echocardiography, which provides detailed information about the structure and function of the heart; electrocardiography (ECG), which assesses the electrical activity of the heart; and cardiac stress testing, which evaluates the heart's response to exercise. He is also likely skilled in interpreting more advanced diagnostic tests such as cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and cardiac catheterization, which provide detailed anatomical and physiological information about the heart.

On the therapeutic side, Dr. Anker's expertise likely encompasses a comprehensive knowledge of the pharmacological management of heart failure. This includes the use of diuretics to reduce fluid overload, ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) to lower blood pressure and improve heart function, beta-blockers to slow down the heart rate and reduce the workload on the heart, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs) to block the effects of aldosterone, a hormone that can contribute to heart failure. He is also likely familiar with newer medications such as angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors (ARNIs) and sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors, which have shown promising results in improving outcomes for patients with heart failure.

In addition to pharmacological therapies, Dr. Anker's expertise likely extends to device-based therapies for heart failure. This includes the use of implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) to prevent sudden cardiac death in patients at high risk of ventricular arrhythmias, cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) to improve the coordination of the heart's contractions in patients with conduction abnormalities, and left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) to provide mechanical support to the failing heart in patients with advanced heart failure. He would also be deeply knowledgeable in the selection and management of patients undergoing cardiac transplantation.

Dr. Anker's clinical expertise likely also encompasses the management of comorbidities commonly associated with heart failure, such as diabetes, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and atrial fibrillation. He likely understands the importance of addressing these comorbidities in order to optimize outcomes for patients with heart failure.
